"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that HIV/AIDS is predicted to become the worst infectious disease epidemic in history, surpassing past pandemics like the bubonic plague and the 1918 influenza outbreak. The gap in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries is widening, endangering progress in child survival. The number of AIDS orphans worldwide is expected to triple in the next decade at current infection rates. The National Intelligence Council predicts a dramatic increase in AIDS orphans worldwide due to current infection rates, leading to economic decay and social issues. The economic costs of infectious diseases, especially HIV/AIDS, could reduce GDP by 20% in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. Some developing nations have successfully implemented prevention programs to curb HIV infection rates. Some developing nations like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have implemented successful HIV prevention programs. United States financial support for global medical research and disease containment has benefits for all Americans. A contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria would be a significant step in combating infectious diseases worldwide. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the International Monetary Fund has not been implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the International Monetary Fund has not been implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. The amendment has been accepted by 109 out of 110 members of the IMF, with the US holding 17.16% of the voting power. Approval by the US would enable the allocation of Special Drawing Rights. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria leverages resources from donor nations to combat the HIV/AIDS crisis. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to accept the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The United States Governor of the Fund accepts the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The Secretary of the Treasury will seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights and provide contributions in fiscal years 2004 through 2006. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide 1/3 of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Additionally, negotiations will be pursued to encourage other Fund members to contribute their allocated Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund.
